answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello, 
While looking into your question I was unable to find any examples of such measures being taken by local government jurisdictions. I was only able to find examples of this type of credit reporting done through privately owned utilities. Yet, even in the private sector this practice seems very new and limited.
The Political and Economic Research Council of The Brookings Institution Urban Markets Initiative conducted land mark research on the topic as presented in this report.
http://perc.net/files/downloads/alt_data.pdf 
In another report from The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Asset Builders of America Inc. they include more case studies of actual firms that have done full reporting to private credit score agencies. 
http://www.assetbuilders.org/pdf/PAID-Casefor_final.pdf 
One of the most recent studies points to two successful applications of reporting utilities to the credit score agency Trans Union. 
The two places are:
1-  Nicor Gas is located in Naperville, Illinois
http://perc.net/files/bizcase_0.pdf  pg 31
2-  DTE Energy is based out of Detroit, Michigan 
http://perc.net/files/bizcase_0.pdf  pg 35
Even if your jurisdiction is unable to make such arrangements with your local utility providers and credit agencies there are other options for individuals and small businesses. This website has a lot of information for those seeking to establish a credit score through alternative means. 
http://www.microbilt.com/nontraditional-credit-report.aspx 
I hope this helps and best of luck getting your idea off the ground.
Is there anyone on the Knowledge Network that knows of a jurisdiction working with credit score agencies?
Ali Iannolo
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

answers.author: Maria Bias
answers.text:
Hello.
I believe that our local jurisdiction does this for water utilities but in my area for building permits, I don't think it would work.  As we deal with homeowners, but we also deal with a lot of contractors that are set up to pay their accounts by credit cards, credit reporting would not work in this instance because the amounts of their bills change each week.  And the individual homeowners, is usually a one-time payment for a permit.  But, I am not sure that when someone bounces a check, their checks are referred to a collection agency.  If unpaid, this may go to the credit reporting agency, eventually.

author: Lourdes Avalos
text:
Has your jurisdiction considered providing payment history information to reporting agencies, in an effort to help residents establish credit?
We realize that many of our residents have trouble acquiring loans (either private or from our government programs) because of lack of credit.  They may only have their utilities payment history (water bill, waste collection, electricity) to speak for them.   We're wondering if any other jurisdiction has ever considered reporting payment history to the private credit reporting agencies to help them build their credit score..
title: Customer Payment History Reporting
